ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Matrix multiplication, determinants, eigenvalues and vectors.
This course is hard if youre not familiar with the concepts and is very poorly structured.
linear transformations, matrices, independence, subspaces, spaces; general introduction to linear algebra
The ability to perform operations on matrices. Understanding of many different terms and the ability to solve for x in Ax = b and Ax = 0.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I found the professor for my section, Professor Aizenbud, particularly engaging and approachable. I think his teaching style played a significant role in allowing me to understand the material (and pay attention in class).

Strengths: math stack exchange is a great resource when you don't understand psets
Weaknesses: terrible explanations/lectures, consistently difficult to comprehend anything, you are essentially teaching yourself, unclear guidance for exams, abysmal organization

I feel as though there was a disconnect in organization between the professors, TA, and ULAs. More coordination and organization would have helped me feel more confident in the course when I went to different people for questions.
There are absolutely no resources for this class. No slides, no readings, no notes. It was awfully hard to get any kind of help.

you go through a lot of material; the course starts slow, but at one point it start moving qucikly and you have to stay on top of it; there is a lot of memorization; i wish we got a formula sheet on exams with important formulas and relationships we had to memorize

Strengths: great notes on the board. Regular and helpful office hours and ULA sessions.
Weaknesses: linear algebra never really clicked for me. Even though everything is related, it seemed like we were receiving a lot of unrelated definitions. I had trouble seeing the bigger picture and felt lost.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Honestly, if you're taking this course, you probably have to. It's one of the foundational building blocks for a lot of upper-level courses in engineering, physics, etc. That said, if you're deciding between this class and 225, and you're an engineering major, definitely take this course. It's much better than struggling through hours of proofs and nice to actually deal with numbers. However, the teaching and organization of this class were quite abysmal. Yariv is a sweet man who really is trying to explain linear algebra to us, but he just cannot. His explanations just didn't make much sense, and although he tried to keep us engaged, we just weren't comprehending enough to ask questions that would have helped us. The teaching staff also didn't give us a list of topics to study or a practice exam for the midterms. We were given a list of questions that "do not necessarily closely mirror those on the exam." Furthermore, in regards to the sample solutions for these problems, it was noted that "As these are "sample" solutions that I produced, it may contain typos, incorrect answers, and some incomplete explanations. (At some parts, I deliberately did so.)" It was consistently frustrating to try and study for exams while knowing that the problems provided would not completely prepare us for the exam. Additionally, psets and practice problems were often posted late, less than a week before the deadline or exam. It felt like the 3 professors who were co-teaching did not know who was in charge and were just content to leave all planning up until the last minute when students were bugging them too much so they couldn't ignore it anymore. Thus, I wouldn't necessarily recommend this class to anyone, but you probably have to take it, so just mentally prepare yourself for frustration.
I cannot in good conscience recommend this class to anyone else if they're not already familiar with the concepts or can put in the effort to learn everything on their own.
i enjoyed the class. i think that the linear algebra problems were fun and prof. Aizenbud is super nice.
I would recommend it if it's required for your major. In theory I appreciate the skills we learned, but it was a challenge for me.
